head.title: Senator Undergoes Surgery for Brain Hemorrhage

hedline.hl1: Senator Undergoes Surgery for Brain Hemorrhage

abstract.p: Sen Paul Coverdell, Georgia Republican, undergoes surgery for cerebral hemorrhage; photo (M)

block.p: Senator Paul Coverdell of Georgia, a top Senate Republican leader, underwent brain surgery for a cerebral hemorrhage today.

The operation, which relieved pressure caused by the bleeding, was performed by Dr. Gary Gropper at Piedmont Hospital in Atlanta, Mr. Coverdell's hometown. Dr. Gropper described the two-hour procedure as a success but said it was still unclear whether the 61-year-old senator would experience any lasting effects from the hemorrhage.
Senator Paul Coverdell of Georgia, a top Senate Republican leader, underwent brain surgery for a cerebral hemorrhage today.

The operation, which relieved pressure caused by the bleeding, was performed by Dr. Gary Gropper at Piedmont Hospital in Atlanta, Mr. Coverdell's hometown. Dr. Gropper described the two-hour procedure as a success but said it was still unclear whether the 61-year-old senator would experience any lasting effects from the hemorrhage.
Mr. Coverdell is in serious condition and will remain in the intensive care unit.

''I think over the next 48 hours we'll have a better idea how he's doing,'' Dr. Gropper said at a hospital news conference where he was joined by Senator Bill Frist, Republican of Tennessee, a heart surgeon who is a close friend of Mr. Coverdell.

Mr. Coverdell arrived at the hospital on Saturday evening after severe headaches. Tests found the hemorrhage, in his temporal lobe, and doctors ordered the surgery today after his condition deteriorated.
A hospital spokeswoman, Nina Montanaro, said Mr. Coverdell did not lose consciousness or suffer any seizures that she knew of before the surgery.

In a statement issued this afternoon, immediately after the operation, Mr. Coverdell's office said, ''The doctors were successful in accomplishing their objective -- the hemorrhage has been stabilized.''

The industrious and self-effacing Mr. Coverdell was elected to the Senate in 1992 and quickly climbed the ranks of the Republican leadership. He is now secretary of the Republican conference, No. 4 among the leadership, and a confidant of the majority leader, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi. Before coming to Capitol Hill, he was a longtime minority leader of the Georgia Senate, chairman of the Georgia Republican Party and director of the Peace Corps.
''I don't know of any senator who works any harder or has a more indomitable spirit,'' Mr. Lott said on the Senate floor today. ''Our thoughts and our prayers are with him.''

Mr. Coverdell is also Senate liaison for Gov. George W. Bush, the presumed Republican presidential nominee, and had spent the last few weeks preparing for the Republican National Convention in Philadelphia.
